hints_html: Two equations and three unknowns, what does that mean for the size of the matrix we are looking for?
hints_latex:
Two equations and three unknowns, what does that mean for the size of
the matrix we are looking for?
hints_raw: Two equations and three unknowns, what does that mean for the size of the matrix we are looking for?
question: B 06 (b)
sols_html:
We have 2 equations in 3 unknowns so the original matrix is \(2\times{3}\). Such a system always has infinitely many solutions and hence at least one free variable. Denote the components of the solution vector x as \(x_1\), \(x_2\), and \(x_3\). The solution we are given suggests x3 = t as the free variable. Further

\[\begin{aligned} x_1&=1+t\\ x_2&=2\\ x_3&=t\end{aligned}\]

Therefore \(x_1=1+x_3\) or \(x_1-x_3=1\). This means we can write our augmented matrix as

\[\begin{aligned} \left[\begin{array}{ccc|c} 1 & 0 & -1 & 1\\ 0 & 1 & 0 & 2 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We have 2 equations in 3 unknowns so the original matrix is
$2\times{3}$. Such a system always has infinitely many solutions and
hence at least one free variable. Denote the components of the solution
vector \textbf{x} as $x_1$, $x_2$, and $x_3$. The solution we are given
suggests \emph{x\textsubscript{3} = t} as the free variable. Further

\begin{align*}
x_1&=1+t\\
x_2&=2\\
x_3&=t
\end{align*}

Therefore $x_1=1+x_3$ or $x_1-x_3=1$. This means we can write our
augmented matrix as

\begin{align*}
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1  &  0  &  -1  &  1\\
0  &  1  &  0  &  2
\end{array}\right]
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We have 2 equations in 3 unknowns so the original matrix is <math>2\times{3}</math>. Such a system always has infinitely many solutions and hence at least one free variable. Denote the components of the solution vector '''x''' as <math>x_1</math>, <math>x_2</math>, and <math>x_3</math>. The solution we are given suggests ''x<sub>3</sub> = t'' as the free variable. Further

:<math>
\begin{align}
x_1&=1+t\\
x_2&=2\\
x_3&=t
\end{align}
</math>

Therefore <math>x_1=1+x_3</math> or <math>x_1-x_3=1</math>.  This means we can write our augmented matrix as

:<math>
\left[\begin{array}{ccc|c}
1  &  0  &  -1  &  1\\
0  &  1  &  0  &  2
\end{array}\right]
</math>
statement_html:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a single, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Two equations in three unknowns with solutions

\[\begin{aligned} \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 2\\ 0 \end{bmatrix}+ t \begin{bmatrix} 1\\ 0\\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\end{aligned}\]

where t is a parameter.
statement_latex:
Consider the linear systems described below. In cases (a)-(d), write a
\emph{single}, possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix
of the system.

Two equations in three unknowns with solutions

\begin{align*}
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0
\end{bmatrix}+
t
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}

where t is a parameter.
statement_raw:
Consider the linear systems described below.  In cases (a)-(d), write a ''single'', possible reduced row echelon form of the augmented matrix of the system.

Two equations in three unknowns with solutions

:<math>
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
2\\
0
\end{bmatrix}+
t
\begin{bmatrix}
1\\
0\\
1
\end{bmatrix}
</math>

where t is a parameter.
